criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states, 'Treatment depends on stage (localized vs. advanced/metastatic)'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a preferred option for resectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes surgery (Whipple, distal pancreatectomy) and indicates it is considered when disease is localized and has not spread, consistent with resectable disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes chemotherapy regimens and states it is given 'for advanced disease,' implying it is the main systemic treatment in metastatic/unresectable settings.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes radiation therapy and mentions use in combination with surgery (e.g., after Whipple), which applies to localized disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the concept of resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly discuss resectability categories (resectable/borderline/locally advanced unresectable); only mentions 'localized vs. advanced.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify the main chemotherapy regimens used are FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine (with capecitabine) but does not specify gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel as a main regimen.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy and that its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: States immunotherapy applies for high microsatellite instability or dMMR; however, it incorrectly suggests pembrolizumab + chemotherapy rather than monotherapy, but the limited role to MSI-H/dMMR is conveyed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib) for tumors with BRCA1/2 or other DNA repair mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages consideration of clinical trials and provides ClinicalTrials.gov as a resource.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that symptom management is an important part of the care of patients with pancreatic cancer and should highlight the importance of supportive care, including evaluation by a palliative care specialist and nutritional support.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses palliative care and symptom management but does not mention nutritional support or dietitian involvement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the location of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Differentiates surgical approaches by location (Whipple for head tumors; distal pancreatectomy for body/tail), indicating treatment depends on tumor location.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the NCCN Panel recommends that decisions about diagnosis and management involve multidisciplinary teams at high-volume centers with appropriate high-volume imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention NCCN recommendations, multidisciplinary teams, high-volume centers, or specialized imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the treatment of pancreatic cancer with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises, 'Always consult your oncologist or healthcare provider for advice tailored to your specific case.'

criterion_scores.description: Provide a direct link to a list of NCI-designated cancer centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response links to NCI resources (PDQ contact and a 'team-science-initiative' page) but does not provide a direct link to the official list of NCI-designated cancer centers.

criterion_scores.description: Discuss resectability in pancreatic cancer, stating that involvement of major blood vessels like the celiac artery generally precludes safe resection and requires evaluation at a specialized center.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response notes complexity with celiac artery involvement and suggests specialized centers, it does not explicitly state that major vessel involvement generally precludes safe resection nor discuss resectability status.

criterion_scores.description: Emphasize evaluation by a multidisciplinary clinic, including surgical, medical, and radiation oncology.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly recommends multidisciplinary clinics and names surgeons, medical/radiation oncologists, and radiologists, emphasizing their importance for complex cases.

criterion_scores.description: Clearly state that neoadjuvant treatment may be proposed to shrink the tumor to a resectable size, but some tumors may remain unresectable and only amenable to systemic therapy or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: Neoadjuvant therapy and downstaging are not mentioned; the response only references clinical trials and radiation without framing them in the context of resectability or neoadjuvant intent.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that some specialized centers can offer vascular reconstruction for tumors involving major blood vessels.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references vascular resection expertise and collaboration with vascular surgeons but does not explicitly state the availability of vascular reconstruction.

criterion_scores.description: Offer to search for high-volume pancreatic cancer programs by preferred location, requesting specific location details to tailor recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response suggests ways to search and lists resources but does not offer to perform a tailored search or ask for the user’s specific location.

criterion_scores.description: State that the NCCN Panel (version 2.2025) recommends that decisions about diagnosis and management involve multidisciplinary teams at high-volume centers with appropriate high-volume imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of NCCN, version 2.2025, or the specific recommendation regarding high-volume centers and imaging studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include an overview of the criteria for resection of the tumor and why patients are deemed not to be good candidates for surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: The response offers general reasons surgery might not be pursued (tumor size/location, trial protocol timing) but does not provide an overview of pancreatic cancer resectability criteria (e.g., involvement of major vessels such as SMA/SMV/portal vein, absence of distant metastases, performance status, radiographic/biomarker response after neoadjuvant therapy). It lacks a structured explanation of resectable vs borderline resectable vs locally advanced criteria and specific reasons patients are deemed unresectable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that the case should be discussed at a multidisciplinary tumor board.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it recommends multidisciplinary input in general terms and consulting a surgical oncologist, it does not explicitly recommend presentation at a multidisciplinary tumor board, which is a key element for pancreatic cancer surgical decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that the patient could seek a second opinion at another specialized center.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises seeking a second opinion and consulting a surgical oncologist, which reasonably conveys the idea of obtaining a specialized second opinion. While it does not specify 'another specialized center,' the recommendation to seek a second opinion from a surgical oncologist meets the core requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide a list of specialized centers that offer second opinions.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific high-volume pancreatic cancer centers or institutions are listed. The response mentions general resources (NCI, ASCO) but does not provide a list of centers offering second opinions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the person discuss surgery with the current oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises discussing with the oncologist/clinical trial team and asking why surgery is not an option, timelines, and whether surgery could become feasible, which fulfills this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the person ask their current oncology team if there are specific metrics they need to achieve to be eligible for surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly suggests asking about specific milestones (e.g., tumor shrinkage, response to treatment) that need to be met before surgery becomes feasible, which aligns with asking about eligibility metrics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list PANCAN Online Community as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (though written as 'PCAN') and notes online/virtual support options for families. This fulfills listing PanCAN as an online resource, despite a minor naming inconsistency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the American Cancer Society (ACS) online community as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions ACS Support Communities and the Cancer Survivors Network.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include CancerCare Online Support Groups as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists CancerCare and describes its free online support groups led by oncology social workers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include various Facebook support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends Facebook groups and provides example group names for pancreatic cancer caregivers/families.

criterion_scores.description: The response should affirm that there are many online support groups for families of pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Opening sentence clearly affirms the availability of several reputable online support groups for family members.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend talking to your family member’s oncology about support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises asking the loved one’s medical team for recommendations on support resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that while chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer, it is still not common to develop pancreatic cancer even in patients with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states chronic pancreatitis increases risk but that the absolute risk remains relatively low and that not everyone with pancreatitis develops cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer support for having experienced the symptoms of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy and acknowledges the challenges of chronic pancreatitis and limited access to care, providing supportive tone and validation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the potential signs and symptoms of pancreatic cancer, which could include unintentional weight loss, jaundice, steatorrhea, new onset diabetes, and worsening of abdominal symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple relevant warning signs: severe/worsening abdominal pain, jaundice, unexplained weight loss, nausea/vomiting, and new-onset diabetes. While steatorrhea is not mentioned, several key symptoms are covered.

criterion_scores.description: The response should outline at least three options for obtaining medical attention without insurance or for low-income adults, such as Federally Qualified Health Centers, community health clinics, Medicaid, or ACA marketplace plans, and should include specific examples or resources when possible.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple concrete options and resources: FQHCs and community clinics with sliding-scale fees, hospital charity care and payment plans, Medicaid, Medicare, HealthCare.gov, FreeClinicDirectory.org, NeedyMeds.org, and Patient Advocate Foundation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that a consultation with a physician who may obtain labs, perform a physical exam, and obtain imaging studies such as a CT scan would be warranted.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends seeking medical attention and specifies appropriate diagnostics: imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI, EUS) and blood tests (e.g., CA 19-9). Encourages referral to gastroenterology/pancreas specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer information on how to sign up for Medicaid and provide more specific instructions and information about eligibility depending on the state the person resides in.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions looking into state Medicaid programs and using HealthCare.gov but does not provide sign-up steps, state-specific eligibility details, or instructions on applying through state Medicaid agencies.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing financial concerns with a doctor, including at least one practical suggestion (e.g., payment plans, charity care).
criterion_scores.justification: Provides practical financial suggestions (charity care, payment plans) but does not explicitly advise discussing financial concerns with the doctor or care team.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide support and note that it is normal to feel overwhelmed under the circumstance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response is empathetic and explicitly normalizes the user's feelings (e.g., 'it’s completely normal to feel helpless, scared, or uncertain' and 'It’s okay to feel overwhelmed'), offering supportive guidance throughout.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide links to websites that give more information on pancreatic cancer that are written at the level of patients and their families.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes patient-friendly resource links to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (https://www.pancan.org) and the American Cancer Society (https://www.cancer.org), both of which provide patient- and caregiver-focused information.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information about online support groups for pancreatic cancer patients and caregivers, including those offered by the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), the American Cancer Society (ACS), and CancerCare.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions support groups generally and references PanCAN and ACS, it does not mention CancerCare or its online support groups. The criterion requires inclusion of PanCAN, ACS, and CancerCare.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide a link to ClinicalTrials.gov for information on clinical trial options.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes a direct link to ClinicalTrials.gov in the Key Resources section (https://clinicaltrials.gov/).

criterion_scores.description: The answer should offer to search for treatment options by location.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions major cancer centers and trial-matching tools, it does not offer to search by location or invite the user to provide a location for tailored options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explicitly suggest obtaining a second opinion from another oncologist or major cancer center and provide a list of leading cancer centers that offer second opinion consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists major cancer centers (MSK, MD Anderson, Johns Hopkins) but does not explicitly recommend obtaining a second opinion or specify that these centers offer second-opinion consultations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide an overview of active areas of research in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It covers multiple active research areas, including targeted therapies (KRAS, BRAF, HER2), immunotherapy (checkpoint inhibitors, combinations), CAR-T, basket/adaptive trials, tumor-agnostic approaches, epigenetic and metabolic therapies. Note: there is a medical inaccuracy regarding erdafitinib being FDA-approved for pancreatic cancer (it is not), but the overview of research areas is present.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide support and acknowledge the difficulty of the situation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response acknowledges the challenging situation, emphasizes quality of life, recommends palliative/supportive care, and mentions emotional support resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend discussing clinical trial options and eligibility with the oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Section 1 explicitly advises discussing clinical trials with the oncologist and notes they can assess eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: Provide support and acknowledge that feeling overwhelmed is understandable and valid.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens by acknowledging that a stage IV diagnosis can be overwhelming and maintains a supportive, compassionate tone throughout, including a reassuring final note.

criterion_scores.description: Provide an overview of what a Stage IV diagnosis entails.
criterion_scores.justification: While it references confirming the extent of spread and discusses palliative/hospice care, it does not clearly explain that stage IV pancreatic cancer indicates metastatic disease, is generally not curable, and that treatment is primarily palliative; thus, it lacks a direct overview of what stage IV entails.

criterion_scores.description: Identify members of the patient care team, including a medical oncologist and palliative care physician.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly mentions the oncologist and recommends integrating palliative care early; it also references other team members (dietitian, counselors, chaplain, social work/home health), satisfying the requirement to include oncologist and palliative care as part of the care team.

criterion_scores.description: Outline the general approach to treatment of stage IV pancreatic cancer, emphasizing that chemotherapy with palliative intent is the cornerstone.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists chemotherapy regimens (e.g., FOLFIRINOX, gemcitabine) as standard treatments, notes radiation for symptom control, and emphasizes early palliative care and hospice when appropriate. This conveys that management is palliative-focused with chemotherapy as the mainstay.

criterion_scores.description: Emphasize the importance of support and community for patients and caregivers, mentioning PanCAN, ACS, and CancerCare as key resources for online support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: The response highlights support groups and counseling for both patients and caregivers and specifically names PanCAN, the American Cancer Society, and CancerCare as resources.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly recommend discussing the diagnosis and next steps with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises clarifying the diagnosis with the oncologist, writing down questions for the oncologist, and consulting about emerging therapies and palliative care, thereby explicitly recommending discussion of diagnosis and next steps with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must recommend discussing vitamins and supplements with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly emphasizes consulting the oncologist and oncology dietitian before starting supplements and notes potential interactions with chemotherapy and other medications.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must recommend maintaining a healthy and balanced diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Section 4 explicitly recommends a balanced, nutrient-dense diet, hydration, and appropriate physical activity, and suggests working with a dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must explicitly state that any diet or high-dose vitamins claiming to cure cancer should be avoided.
criterion_scores.justification: While it states 'Supplements ≠ Cure' and advises against high-dose antioxidants due to possible interference with chemotherapy, it does not explicitly instruct to avoid any diets or high-dose vitamins that claim to cure cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must mention the benefit of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) or its benefits appears in the response.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that due to malabsorption in pancreatic cancer, supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) is recommended, and should note that lab-confirmed vitamin deficiencies can be improved with appropriate vitamin supplements under the direction of a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses vitamin D testing and supplementation broadly but does not address pancreatic cancer–related malabsorption, the need for A, D, E, and K supplementation, or correcting lab-confirmed deficiencies under physician direction.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that pancreatic enzyme deficiency is common in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention pancreatic enzyme deficiency or its prevalence in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their goals of care and potential treatment side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises consulting the medical team and oncologist, and provides specific prompts to discuss goals and side effects (e.g., "please consult your loved one’s medical team," "Discuss with the oncologist," and "Ask the Medical Team Hard Questions" including goals and side-effect management).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the decision to continue with chemotherapy treatments is highly personal.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states there is "no one-size-fits-all answer," that the decision is "agonizing," and "depends entirely on your loved one’s values."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes to the chemotherapy dose can improve side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions "dose reductions" as a way to help with side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes to the chemotherapy schedule can improve side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes it’s okay to pause treatment to reassess, it does not explicitly state that changing the chemotherapy schedule (e.g., timing or spacing) can improve side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes to supportive medications can improve side effect symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions supportive care and specific supportive medications such as anti-nausea drugs and hydration that can help manage side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient ask for a referral to a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it recommends integrating palliative care, it does not explicitly advise asking for a referral to a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: It opens with empathetic language: "I’m truly sorry to hear about your loved one’s diagnosis..." and acknowledges the emotional difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that deferring further cancer-directed treatment and pursuing palliative care and hospice would be a valid approach.
criterion_scores.justification: It states palliative care can be provided instead of chemotherapy and discusses hospice as an appropriate option when focusing on comfort, affirming this as a valid approach.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that somatic testing can be done on the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response asks which tests were performed and how the sample was obtained (e.g., tumor biopsy from the pancreas or liver metastasis) and explicitly distinguishes somatic vs. germline mutations, indicating tumor/somatic testing.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that germline testing is appropriate.
criterion_scores.justification: It addresses hereditary (germline) vs. somatic mutations and includes a dedicated 'Hereditary Cancer Risk' section recommending consideration of genetic counseling/testing for family members, indicating appropriateness of germline testing.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should discuss testing for BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: BRCA1/2 are explicitly listed among genes analyzed and are referenced in treatment implications.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should discuss the role of utilizing PARP inhibitors in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: PARP inhibitors are mentioned as examples of targeted therapies for BRCA1/2 mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should include an overview of testing for microsatellite instability and MSI status, which can be a marker for response to immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of MSI, mismatch repair deficiency, or immunotherapy biomarkers is present.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should include other potential targetable mutations such as HER2/ERBB2 amplification and NTRK.
criterion_scores.justification: HER2/ERBB2 and NTRK are not mentioned; only other genes like BRAF and PIK3CA are cited.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that clinical trials may be available for less commonly targeted mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Clinical Trials' section prompts asking about trials that target the specific mutations found and how to enroll, implying availability for uncommon/rare alterations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should recommend that the patient consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly recommends genetic counseling, detailing how a counselor can assess family history, evaluate risk, and guide testing and management.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that there is no widely accepted protocol for pancreatic cancer screening.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states pancreatic cancer screening is "less standardized than for other cancers" but does not clearly state that there is no widely accepted screening protocol. It also cites guidelines suggesting screening for certain high-risk groups, which could imply the existence of a protocol.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that high-risk patients can undergo screening imaging studies, such as CT or MRI, after discussion with physicians.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises consultation with specialists and mentions imaging options (EUS, CT, MRI) in the context of screening for high-risk individuals, including reference to guidelines and typical starting ages.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe hereditary syndromes that increase the risk of pancreatic cancer and note that germline BRCA mutations are a significant genetic risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses inherited genetic risk, cites specific genes (BRCA1/2, CDKN2A, PALB2), and links these to broader hereditary cancer risks (e.g., breast/ovarian/prostate), thereby addressing hereditary syndromes and highlighting BRCA as a significant risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should recommend testing for selected mutations such as BRCA and CDKN2A.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends genetic counseling with a plan to "recommend testing for hereditary cancer syndromes" and explicitly lists relevant mutations (BRCA1/2, CDKN2A, PALB2), satisfying the requirement to recommend testing for selected mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that doctors use imaging results to determine response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly mentions that oncologists use imaging scans (CT, MRI, PET) to assess tumor shrinkage or growth when evaluating treatment effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 is one part of what determines response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that CA 19-9 is a tumor marker and not a standalone indicator, and emphasizes using it alongside scans, symptoms, and other labs to assess response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 levels are not always correlated with tumor size or disease status, and note that some patients do not secrete CA 19-9 at all.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response discusses fluctuations and limitations of CA 19-9, it does not explicitly state that some patients do not secrete CA 19-9 (e.g., Lewis antigen–negative) and does not clearly state lack of correlation with tumor size/disease status.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if CA 19-9 is reflective of cancer activity, it would be expected to decrease with effective chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes reasons for stable CA 19-9 and that CA 19-9 may lag behind clinical response, but it does not explicitly state that CA 19-9 would be expected to decrease when therapy is effective if it reflects cancer activity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define CA 19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines CA 19-9 as a protein tumor marker often elevated in pancreatic cancer and some other cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that doctors use changes in symptoms to determine response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly includes symptoms (improving, worsening, stable) as part of how oncologists evaluate treatment effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the CA 19-9 test results with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises consulting the oncologist, asking for an explanation of CA 19-9 results alongside scans, and requesting a treatment review.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that it is not an unexpected outcome as removing pancreas tissue will also take the islet cells which produce insulin.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly explains that Whipple surgery removes pancreatic tissue containing insulin-producing beta cells and states the outcome is a recognized, not unexpected complication.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the incidence of post-Whipple diabetes, noting it can vary based on how much of the pancreas is removed and the specific patient population, occurring in 15-20% to up to 50% of patients.
criterion_scores.justification: It reports an incidence of ~20–50% and notes variability based on extent of pancreatic removal and other factors, which aligns with the rubric’s range and context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the control of diabetes is achieved through regulating glucose intake via dietary modifications and medications that can help control blood sugars.
criterion_scores.justification: The response covers dietary adjustments (small frequent meals, low-glycemic carbs, limiting sugars) and medications (insulin and consideration of oral agents), clearly addressing glucose regulation via diet and pharmacotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the father of the question writer should be evaluated by an endocrinologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends working with an endocrinologist as part of the healthcare team for a personalized management plan.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the father may ultimately require insulin injections to regulate his blood sugars.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states insulin injections may be necessary and are often the most effective treatment for type 3c diabetes.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that anorexia and weight loss are common symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response acknowledges that pancreatic cancer can lead to weight loss and mentions loss of appetite as a treatment side effect, but it does not explicitly state that anorexia and weight loss are common symptoms of pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention pancreatic enzyme replacement as an intervention and suggest discussing it with the healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) is explicitly recommended (e.g., Creon, Pancreaze, Ultresa), and the response advises working with the doctor to adjust doses and ensure proper use.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend consulting a registered dietitian specializing in oncology for personalized nutritional advice.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends a registered dietitian specializing in oncology to create a tailored meal plan.

criterion_scores.description: The response must advise consuming nutrient-dense foods and eating smaller, more frequent meals, and explicitly emphasize the importance of maintaining adequate protein and calorie intake.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises high-calorie, nutrient-dense foods, suggests small, frequent meals, and includes protein-focused options (e.g., smoothies with protein powder), thereby emphasizing calorie and protein intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response must suggest nutritional supplementation with high-calorie meal replacement shakes and explicitly state that nutrition or protein supplements can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends oral nutritional supplements such as Ensure/Boost to boost calorie intake and suggests smoothies/shakes with protein powder, clearly endorsing nutrition/protein supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the patient should discuss their weight loss with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: While it advises consulting healthcare professionals and working with the medical team, it does not explicitly direct the patient to discuss their weight loss with their oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention chemotherapy as a potential cause of weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: The response refers to treatment side effects generally but does not explicitly mention chemotherapy as a cause of weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must specify that jaundice is due to an increase in bilirubin in the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that jaundice occurs when there’s a buildup of bilirubin in the bloodstream and also mentions conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly notes that elevated bilirubin causes a yellow tint to the skin and eyes.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that jaundice can arise in pancreatic cancer due to blockage of the bile duct from tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains that a tumor in the head of the pancreas can block or compress the bile duct, preventing bile flow and leading to jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is used to visualize the blocked duct and place a stent to relieve the blockage.
criterion_scores.justification: ERCP is described as using an endoscope to visualize the bile ducts and place a stent to keep the duct open, relieving obstruction.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that other options to relieve the obstruction include percutaneous biliary drainage or surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography for drainage/stenting and surgical bile duct bypass as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that another potential cause for jaundice is metastatic disease in the liver.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention liver metastases as a cause of jaundice; it focuses on bile duct obstruction from the primary pancreatic tumor.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that treating the cancer with chemotherapy can shrink the tumor and help address the jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that chemotherapy or radiation may shrink the tumor and reduce obstruction, thereby addressing jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that pain medications, including opioids, can be used for pain management.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly describes opioid use (morphine, fentanyl, oxycodone, hydromorphone), dosing considerations, and long-acting vs short-acting formulations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should describe procedures, such as a celiac plexus block, that can help alleviate pain.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of celiac plexus block/neurolysis or other interventional pain procedures.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should express sympathy for the diagnosis and symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy (“I'm truly sorry to hear about your husband's diagnosis”) and maintains a supportive tone.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that adjunctive non-opioid medications, such as amitriptyline and gabapentin, can be used.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists adjuvants including antidepressants (amitriptyline, duloxetine) and anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin) for neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that steroids, such as dexamethasone, can also be used.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions corticosteroids as a pain-reducing option; although dexamethasone is not named specifically, the class is appropriately cited.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that radiation can be used for local treatment and pain control.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention radiation therapy for local control or pain relief.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that complementary therapies, such as acupuncture and massages, can also be pursued.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes acupuncture and massage (and TENS) among non-pharmacological options.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that the patient should be seen by a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically highlights palliative care specialists, their role, and the benefit of early integration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing pain management with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages consultation with the oncologist, pain specialist, and palliative care team to individualize pain management.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that resectability is determined by the surgeons’ assessment of their ability to safely remove the entire tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that 'unresectable' means surgery cannot safely or effectively remove the cancer and that this determination is made by the medical team after evaluating tumor characteristics, aligning with the concept of surgical ability to remove the tumor safely.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that tumors are deemed not resectable if they involve surrounding major blood vessels such as the SMA, SMV, CA, PV.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly mentions proximity to and involvement with major blood vessels, giving examples of the superior mesenteric artery and vein (SMA/SMV) and noting that attachment to blood vessels can make safe removal impossible. While CA and PV are not named, the inclusion of SMA/SMV and the concept of vessel involvement satisfy the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that invasion of nearby organs can also lead to a tumor not being able to be resected.
criterion_scores.justification: The response directly addresses invasion of nearby organs (liver, peritoneum, intestines) and explains that such invasion may prevent complete and safe removal, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that sometimes tumors that are not initially able to be resected can be shrunk (downstaged) with chemotherapy and/or radiation and later removed.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that initially unresectable tumors may shrink with chemotherapy or radiation and become resectable later, explicitly naming neoadjuvant therapy and suggesting reassessment for surgery.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should offer sympathy for the loved one’s diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes empathetic language acknowledging the difficulty of the situation, offers emotional support resources, and reassures the reader they are not alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the decision to continue with or stop chemotherapy treatments is highly personal.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, 'Deciding whether to continue or stop cancer treatment is deeply personal,' meeting the criterion clearly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the decision should be made weighing the expected benefit of more therapy with the current side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes balancing benefits and burdens, including questions like 'Are the side effects outweighing the benefits?' and discusses expected benefits vs. side effects in consultation with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their goals of care with their oncology team and suggest meeting with their oncologist and a palliative care physician to help guide decision-making.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting the oncologist to discuss prognosis and goals, and recommends involving palliative care specialists to guide symptom management and decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient ask for a referral to a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: While it encourages exploring palliative care and mentions palliative care specialists, it does not explicitly instruct the patient to ask for a referral to a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe palliative care.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is described as support to manage symptoms, improve comfort, and address emotional needs, and it notes it can be integrated alongside active treatment—an accurate description.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Hospice is described correctly as care typically for those with a prognosis of six months or less, focusing on compassionate support, pain management, and emotional care at home or in a facility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy and state that it is a very difficult decision to try to make.
criterion_scores.justification: The tone is empathetic, acknowledges the complexity and personal nature of the decision, and offers supportive language ('You’re not alone'), fulfilling the sympathy and difficulty acknowledgment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that KRAS mutations are frequently implicated in pancreatic cancer as a major driver of tumorigenesis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that KRAS mutations are common (~90% of cases) and are driver mutations in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the first line of treatment would remain the standard of care with chemotherapy regimens such as FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine/abraxane.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that chemotherapy (e.g., FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine-based regimens) remains first-line regardless of KRAS status.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that there are several KRAS mutations (G12C, G12D, G12V) and specify which one is present in the patient’s case.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions several KRAS variants, it omits G12C in the example list and does not specify the patient's exact KRAS subtype; it only advises confirming it.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that targeted therapy to the KRAS mutation is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that targeted therapies are an emerging area and highlights ongoing research and clinical trials for KRAS-directed treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that some KRAS mutations can be targeted with drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it claims some KRAS mutations can be targeted, it inaccurately states that sotorasib and adagrasib are FDA-approved for KRAS G12D in pancreatic cancer. These agents target KRAS G12C and are not approved for G12D; thus, the content is medically inaccurate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there may be clinical trials for certain KRAS mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: It encourages considering clinical trials and notes that trials are actively exploring inhibitors for specific KRAS subtypes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the patient should discuss their KRAS mutation with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly advises discussing the KRAS subtype and treatment options with the oncologist, including clinical trial eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention recent trials evaluating the use of high-dose vitamin C in combination with chemotherapy for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response cites a randomized phase 2 trial (referred to as VICTOR) combining IV vitamin C with gemcitabine in metastatic pancreatic cancer and a phase 1 trial combining IV vitamin C with chemotherapy in advanced solid tumors including pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that high-dose vitamin C has not been proven to improve outcomes in pancreatic or any other cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states no significant clinical benefit has been demonstrated in pancreatic cancer but does not explicitly state that vitamin C has not been proven to improve outcomes in any other cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the proposed mechanism of action of high-dose vitamin C in conjunction with chemotherapy, noting that it can act as a pro-oxidant by generating hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), which may enhance the killing of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly describes pro-oxidant effects and generation of hydrogen peroxide as a mechanism that may enhance cancer cell killing.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that there is limited published data showing high-dose vitamin C is well tolerated and shows a trend toward efficacy, but studies are limited and not sufficiently powered.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes high-dose IV vitamin C is generally well tolerated, references non-significant trends in outcomes, and emphasizes that small studies suggest possible benefits requiring validation in larger, rigorous trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention possible toxicities of taking high doses of vitamin C.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions higher rates of neutropenia in the vitamin C group and gastrointestinal issues with high oral doses, satisfying the requirement to mention possible toxicities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention drug-drug interactions of vitamin C.
criterion_scores.justification: No drug-drug interactions are discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that vitamin C is not FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not state that high-dose IV vitamin C is not FDA-approved for treating cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that vitamin C is not recommended by the NCCN guideline.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of NCCN guidelines or that high-dose vitamin C is not recommended by them.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that if a patient wishes to use high doses of vitamin C in conjunction with chemotherapy, they should consult with an oncologist regarding the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The conclusion advises patients to consult their oncologist about complementary therapies, meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a biopsy is the only way to confirm the diagnosis of metastatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state that biopsy is the only way to confirm metastasis. It emphasizes imaging and other techniques (e.g., PET-CT, liquid biopsy) and even states that modern imaging can provide more reliable confirmation and that staging can proceed without a confirmed biopsy, which contradicts the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that imaging such as CT or MRI is done to evaluate for the presence of metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly discusses imaging modalities (contrast-enhanced CT, MRI, PET-CT, dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI) to evaluate for liver metastases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that tumor markers can be supportive of a diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state that serum tumor markers (e.g., CA 19-9) can support the diagnosis. It mentions CA19-9 in the context of immunohistochemistry on tissue rather than as a supportive serum marker, and does not make the point that tumor markers can be supportive.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the team may suggest that the patient undergo another biopsy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly recommends repeat or targeted biopsy, including image-guided, core needle, and EUS-guided approaches.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that on occasion the team will decide to treat as metastatic if the tumor markers and imaging are consistent with metastatic disease so as to not delay treatment if a repeat biopsy is not feasible.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response notes that staging may proceed as stage IV based on imaging alone, it does not mention tumor markers as part of that decision, nor does it tie the decision to situations where a repeat biopsy is not feasible to avoid treatment delays.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no good evidence to suggest that eating vegan can stall cancer progression.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states there is no conclusive evidence that veganism stalls progression in existing cancers and clarifies it is not a guaranteed method to stall progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including pancreatic enzyme insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of pancreatic enzyme insufficiency, steatorrhea, or pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy; content remains general to cancer and vegan diets.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including insulin-dependent diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: Insulin-dependent diabetes and glycemic issues related to pancreatic cancer are not discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including biliary obstruction.
criterion_scores.justification: Biliary obstruction and its dietary implications are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including high protein and calorie needs during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address the increased protein and calorie needs common during pancreatic cancer treatment; instead notes vegan diets are often lower in calories.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that nutrition support is often needed for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No statement that nutrition support (e.g., dietitian-guided plans, enteral/parenteral support) is often needed in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussion of diet with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises patients to consult their oncologists to align dietary choices with treatment and nutritional needs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussion of diet with an oncology nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions discussing with healthcare providers and oncologists, it does not specifically recommend consultation with an oncology nutritionist.

criterion_scores.description: States that medical fitness is scored using ECOG or Karnofsky performance status.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly uses ECOG throughout (e.g., 'Patient Performance Status (ECOG)', ECOG 0–1 and ECOG 2).

criterion_scores.description: States that fitter patients are offered FOLFIRINOX; frailer but treatable patients are offered gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly indicates ECOG 0–1 patients often receive FOLFIRINOX and ECOG 2 patients are offered gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel.

criterion_scores.description: States FOLFIRINOX generally for ECOG 0–1; gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel can be given to ECOG 2.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies FOLFIRINOX for ECOG 0–1 and gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel preferred for ECOG 2.

criterion_scores.description: Explains FOLFIRINOX is reserved for good PS because it is more intensive with higher rates of severe side effects such as neutropenia, fatigue, and diarrhea.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes higher toxicity and lists diarrhea and myelosuppression but does not explicitly mention neutropenia or fatigue for FOLFIRINOX, nor describe it as 'more intensive'.

criterion_scores.description: Lists individual drugs in FOLFIRINOX and clarifies nab-paclitaxel is combined with gemcitabine.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, irinotecan, oxaliplatin for FOLFIRINOX and repeatedly refers to gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel.

criterion_scores.description: States there are no head-to-head trials comparing gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel and FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: Incorrectly claims a head-to-head comparison ('NAPOLI Trial: FOLFIRINOX vs. nab-paclitaxel/gemcitabine'), rather than stating none exist.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions age as a factor influencing regimen choice.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly cites age as a reason some patients receive gemcitabine alone.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions comorbid conditions as a factor in selecting a regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated section on organ function and comorbidities influencing regimen selection.

criterion_scores.description: State that resectability is determined by the ability of the surgeon to safely remove the entire tumor and not leave any behind (R0 resection).
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes 'potentially curative surgical removal' but does not explicitly state the goal of an R0 resection or that no tumor can be left behind.

criterion_scores.description: State that involvement of major blood vessels such as the SMA, SMV, CA, PV are often implicated when a tumor is deemed to not be resectable.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly notes major vessel involvement as a determinant of unresectability and specifically mentions SMA, PV, and SMV with encasement thresholds. While CA is not explicitly named, the concept of major vessel involvement is adequately addressed.

criterion_scores.description: State that for pancreatic cancer to be resectable, there must not be any distant metastases.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states 'Absence of Distant Metastasis' with examples (liver, lungs, peritoneum, distant nodes) and imaging confirmation.

criterion_scores.description: State that tumors that contact the veins (PV/SMV) with less than 180 degrees of involvement can still be resected if the vessel can be reconstructed as needed.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that minor vessel abutment may be acceptable and that limited vascular involvement (e.g., short segment PV) may be resectable with vascular resection/reconstruction.

criterion_scores.description: State that some tumors are deemed borderline resectable and recommend chemotherapy and/or radiation to attempt to down-stage and make resection possible.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions 'borderline resectable' tumors but does not recommend neoadjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation to downstage.

criterion_scores.description: Include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including a CT scan.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes contrast-enhanced CT as a key imaging modality.

criterion_scores.description: Include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including an MRI.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes MRI as a key imaging modality.

criterion_scores.description: Include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including a PET scan.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PET scan in the context of evaluating distant metastases.

criterion_scores.description: Include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including an endoscopic ultrasound.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) as an imaging modality to assess tumor and adjacent structures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that family history of pancreas cancer is associated with increased risk.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that having a first-degree relative with pancreatic cancer increases risk (e.g., doubles risk).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a family history of pancreas cancer is due to inherited gene mutations such as BRCA.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes up to 10% are linked to inherited mutations and specifically lists BRCA1/2 among others.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that smoking is a significant modifiable risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies smoking as a major modifiable risk factor and quantifies increased risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly lists chronic pancreatitis as a risk factor and explains mechanism via chronic inflammation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that heavy alcohol use can lead to increased risk of pancreas cancer through pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: States heavy alcohol use increases risk and separately explains alcohol can cause chronic pancreatitis, which raises cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention Lynch syndrome or mismatch repair gene syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention Peutz-Jeghers syndrome or STK11.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions CDKN2A but does not explicitly name the FAMMM syndrome as required.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists PRSS1 among genes but does not explicitly state 'hereditary pancreatitis' as a syndrome/risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including age.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly includes age as a risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies diabetes as a risk factor and briefly explains association.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including obesity.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists obesity as a risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions diet (processed/red meats, saturated fats) as possible contributors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including exposure to certain industrial chemicals.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes occupational exposures such as pesticides and dyes as linked risks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you have a strong family history, discuss with your doctor about screening or genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing family history with a provider and mentions genetic counseling/testing and screening for high-risk individuals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should undergo genetic counseling.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly emphasizes genetic counseling as the first step ('a genetic counseling session is essential first') and reiterates it under 'Next Steps' ('Consult a Genetic Counselor').

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the type of genetic testing depends on the specific family history or hereditary condition.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states testing is based on family history and specific condition, including assessing affected relatives, age of onset, inheritance pattern, and tailoring testing to the patient’s family history.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that single genes can be tested if there is a known condition associated with a specific genetic disorder.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists numerous single-gene tests (e.g., HTT for Huntington’s, CFTR for cystic fibrosis, HBB for sickle cell, FBN1 for Marfan) and notes testing when a pathogenic variant is known in the family.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a panel of genes can be tested for multiple genes.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly discusses 'Multigene panels' that analyze multiple genes simultaneously and provides examples such as hereditary breast cancer panels and cardiomyopathy panels.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide examples of single gene disorders such as Huntington’s Disease, Cystic Fibrosis, and Sickle Cell.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly lists Huntington’s disease (HTT), cystic fibrosis (CFTR), and sickle cell trait/anemia (HBB) as single-gene disorders.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide examples of panel testing for hereditary cancer and cardiomyopathy.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides hereditary cancer panels (e.g., breast cancer panels including PALB2, CHEK2, ATM) and names cardiomyopathy panels as examples under 'Multigene Panels'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the types of clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly listed and described treatment, prevention, diagnostic, and quality-of-life trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that clinical trials are divided into three different phases.
criterion_scores.justification: It described four phases (I–IV) and did not state that trials are divided into three phases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 1 is the first time the drug is tested in humans and is aimed at establishing the safety and dosage.
criterion_scores.justification: It noted Phase I tests safety and dosage but did not state it is the first time tested in humans.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 2 tests the effectiveness of the drug and continues to establish its safety.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly said Phase II evaluates effectiveness and side effects, addressing efficacy and safety.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 3 tests the efficacy of the drug in a larger group of patients and compares it to the current standard of care.
criterion_scores.justification: Stated Phase III compares to standard care in large groups to confirm benefits and monitor risks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe eligibility criteria for clinical trials, including stage of disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Listed several criteria (cancer type, prior treatments, age, organ function) but did not mention disease stage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there can be risks associated with participating in a trial, including potential side effects and lack of efficacy.
criterion_scores.justification: Discussed side effects/unknown risks and that the treatment may not work better than standard care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing clinical trial options with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly advised talking to the oncologist and oncology team about trial options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include clinicaltrials.gov as a resource for finding clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly referenced ClinicalTrials.gov as a resource.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer support for the diagnosis and how difficult it can be to complete 15 rounds of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Expressed general empathy but did not specifically acknowledge the difficulty of completing 15 rounds of chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must include ClinicalTrials.gov as a resource for finding clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly lists ClinicalTrials.gov with a link and identifies it as an NIH resource for finding trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must provide instructions on using the search by location function on ClinicalTrials.gov.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides concrete steps to filter by Location/Region (city, state, or ZIP code) on ClinicalTrials.gov, satisfying the location-search instruction.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention the National Cancer Institute (NCI) website and describe using it to search for trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions the NCI and provides the cancer.gov/clinical-trials link, advising to check it for federally funded trials. This describes using the NCI site to find trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention and provide a link to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) clinical trial finder tool.
criterion_scores.justification: While PanCAN is mentioned with a general link to pancan.org, the specific PanCAN Clinical Trial Finder tool is not named nor linked.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend contacting advocacy organizations for information on clinical trials, including PanCAN.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends partnering with patient advocacy groups and specifically lists the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network as a resource to connect patients to trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend contacting advocacy organizations for information on clinical trials, including the American Cancer Society.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends the American Cancer Society, provides a link, and notes they offer trial-matching tools and support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss clinical trial options with their oncology team and consult with a local healthcare provider or oncologist to explore available trials at nearby cancer centers, as well as contact major cancer centers for additional information on clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises discussing options with an oncologist/primary care physician, contacting local hospitals/cancer centers and major centers, and includes a final step to collaborate with the oncologist to review options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that family history of pancreatic cancer is associated with increased risk.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that first-degree relatives have a 2–3x higher risk and that family history contributes to risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations are genetic risk factors for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations under genetic syndromes linked to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that smoking is a significant modifiable risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies tobacco use as strongly associated, with up to twice the risk in smokers and mentions risk reduction with quitting.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists chronic pancreatitis as significantly raising pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that heavy alcohol use can lead to increased risk of pancreatic cancer through pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes heavy alcohol use as a risk factor and explains it may act via causing chronic pancreatitis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify Lynch syndrome as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly names Lynch syndrome among genetic syndromes linked to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify Peutz-Jeghers syndrome as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: FAMMM is not named; while CDKN2A is mentioned, the syndrome itself is not identified.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatitis as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Hereditary pancreatitis is explicitly listed with PRSS1 mutations noted.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include age as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States risk increases with age, with most cases over 60 and highest incidence at 70+.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include diabetes as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies long-standing type 2 diabetes as a risk factor and discusses possible mechanisms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include obesity as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes obesity/overweight, especially visceral fat, increases risk; mentions BMI relationship.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include diet as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses high processed/red meat intake and low fiber as increasing risk; mentions dietary patterns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include exposure to certain industrial chemicals as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions occupational exposures to chemicals such as benzene and pesticides as potential risk factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you have a strong family history, discuss with your doctor about screening or genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises genetic counseling for those with a strong family history or known mutations, aligning with discussing testing/screening with a healthcare professional.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking for a referral from their primary doctor or oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response begins with 'Start with Your Primary Care Physician (PCP)' and explicitly suggests asking for a referral to a pancreatic cancer specialist or an oncologist with expertise in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend using the PanCAN patient services to find a pancreatic cancer specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically references the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PCAN/PanCAN) and notes their website offers a directory of specialists, which constitutes using PanCAN resources to find a specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend using the American Cancer Society patient services to find a pancreatic cancer specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: While the American Cancer Society (ACS) and its helpline are listed under 'Key Resources to Bookmark,' the response does not explicitly recommend using ACS patient services to locate a specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can reference the NCI website to look for designated cancer centers that have pancreatic cancer specialists on staff.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises visiting Cancer.gov (NCI) for resources and links to specialized centers and mentions looking for 'comprehensive cancer center,' aligning with NCI-designated centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about the nearest cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: The response provides examples of major national centers (e.g., Mayo Clinic, MD Anderson, MSK) but does not include information about the user's nearest cancer center.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend checking with their health insurance provider about in-network pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes a dedicated section to contact the insurance provider, verify coverage, and request a list of in-network pancreatic cancer specialists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define CA 19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines CA 19-9 as a tumor marker and describes it as a substance produced by cancer cells or by the body in response to cancer, with further detail about its antigenic nature. This constitutes a clear and accurate definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 is a tumor marker produced by cancer cells and measurable in the blood, and describe its use in pancreatic cancer, noting that it can serve as a marker for the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states CA 19-9 is a tumor marker, notes it may be produced by cancer cells, specifies it is measured via a blood test, and discusses its primary use in pancreatic cancer for monitoring and as a supportive diagnostic marker.

criterion_scores.description: The response must include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists several non-malignant causes of elevation (pancreatitis, cirrhosis, infections, benign tumors) and notes other cancers, clearly indicating CA 19-9 can be elevated in conditions other than pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that reference ranges can vary by lab.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states: 'The exact normal range may differ slightly between laboratories.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that normal levels are typically less than 37 U/mL but do not rule out cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States typical normal as <37 U/mL and clarifies that normal does not rule out cancer: 'It does not rule out cancer, as some cancers may not produce detectable levels of CA 19-9.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that levels from 37 to 100 U/mL can be associated with non-cancer conditions such as pancreatitis and bile duct disorders.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that elevated levels (>37 U/mL) can occur with non-cancer conditions and lists chronic pancreatitis among causes. While it does not specify the 37–100 range explicitly or bile duct disorders by name, it covers the concept that mild elevations above 37 can be non-malignant with examples (pancreatitis).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that moderate elevation (100-1000 U/mL) can be concerning for cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that levels >100–200 U/mL are more strongly associated with cancer and that >100 U/mL can be a red flag, capturing that moderate elevations can be concerning.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that levels greater than 1000 U/mL can be suggestive of advanced cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of the >1000 U/mL threshold or its association with advanced disease.
