criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the use of CA 19-9 in pancreatic cancer, including that it can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly identifies CA 19-9 as a marker associated with pancreatic cancer and discusses its role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple non-cancerous causes (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, cirrhosis, IBD) and other malignancies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for monitoring the effectiveness of pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states monitoring to assess treatment effectiveness, with decreasing levels indicating success.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for detecting recurrence of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that rising levels could signal return or progression (recurrence).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions elevations in other malignancies such as gastric, colorectal, and lung cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in liver disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists cirrhosis of the liver as a non-cancer cause of elevation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in gallstones.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention gallstones or cholelithiasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated with elevated bilirubin.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of bilirubin elevation or cholestasis/obstructive jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes false negatives ('some cancers may not elevate CA 19-9') and explains Lewis antigen-negative individuals may have undetectable levels, implying that not all pancreatic cancers will produce CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions 'Pancreatitis (Acute or Chronic)' as a cause of elevated CA 19-9 and explains that levels may correlate with severity and normalize with treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with liver diseases like cirrhosis or hepatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Liver Disease' can lead to elevated CA 19-9 due to impaired clearance. While cirrhosis/hepatitis are not named specifically, liver disease as a category is clearly included.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with cholestasis or biliary diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Biliary Obstruction (e.g., choledocholithiasis)' and 'Biliary tract cancers,' both of which are associated with cholestasis and elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with inflammatory bowel disease or gastrointestinal diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists 'Inflammatory Bowel Disease' (Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis) and discusses elevations; also mentions other GI diseases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with infections or other inflammatory conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies multiple inflammatory conditions (pancreatitis, IBD) that can elevate CA 19-9. Although infections are not explicitly mentioned, the criterion allows 'or other inflammatory conditions,' which are clearly included.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States CA 19-9 is 'a tumor marker primarily associated with pancreatic cancer' and reiterates its clinical use.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists several other malignancies (colorectal, gastric, biliary tract, lung, ovarian, breast) where CA 19-9 may be elevated.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that not all pancreatic cancers (or Lewis antigen–negative individuals) produce CA 19-9. The mention of 'genetic polymorphisms may influence production' is vague and insufficient.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing weight loss with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises working closely with the oncologist and an oncology dietitian, discussing medications with the medical team, and communicating concerns to the healthcare team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be taken to help with the absorption of nutrients from foods.
criterion_scores.justification: States that pancreatic enzyme supplements, if prescribed, can aid digestion and nutrient absorption.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that nutritional strategies can be employed, such as focusing on small, frequent meals and nutrient-rich foods, and should recommend including calorie-dense and protein-rich foods in the diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends small, frequent meals and details high-calorie, nutrient-dense, and protein-rich options (e.g., smoothies with protein powder, nut butters, avocados, cheese, olive oil).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that medications for managing nausea can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises use of antiemetics/anti-nausea medications as prescribed and suggests discussing medications with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to chemotherapy side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "treatment side effects" generally and addresses nausea/taste changes, but does not explicitly state chemotherapy-related side effects as a cause of weight loss or explicitly frame multiple causes of weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to pancreatic enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that pancreatic enzyme supplements can aid absorption and mentions malabsorption, but does not explicitly state pancreatic enzyme deficiency as a cause of weight loss or explicitly frame multiple causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include unintentional weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions "Unexplained Weight Loss" and also ties weight loss to loss of appetite.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists "Jaundice" as a symptom and describes it clearly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include new onset diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes "New-Onset Diabetes" with an explanation of mechanism.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include abdominal pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "Abdominal or Back Pain" and describes upper abdominal pain radiating to the back.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer can be difficult to detect early.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes symptom overlap causing delays in diagnosis and states early-stage disease may be asymptomatic, implying difficulty with early detection.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer does not cause symptoms until the disease is advanced.
criterion_scores.justification: States "Early-stage pancreatic cancer may be asymptomatic, while advanced stages are more likely to exhibit noticeable symptoms," conveying that symptoms often appear when disease is advanced.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the reason for jaundice is the blockade of bile ducts.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains jaundice occurs "due to a tumor blocking bile ducts."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that loss of appetite can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists "Loss of Appetite" explicitly as a symptom.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that abdominal bloating or indigestion can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes "Bloating or Abdominal Discomfort," which satisfies this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that foul-smelling stools or steatorrhea can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "Steatorrhea" and describes "greasy, foul-smelling, pale, or oily stools."

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference the American Cancer Society information page on symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No reference to the American Cancer Society information page is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that most pancreatic cancer cases are sporadic and not hereditary.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states pancreatic cancer is primarily sporadic and notes that over 90% of cases are not hereditary.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are hereditary conditions that can lead to pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly acknowledges a hereditary component (5–10%) and links it to inherited genetic mutations and familial syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a strong family history is a significant risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes increased risk with first-degree relatives and greater risk with multiple affected relatives, indicating strong family history as a significant risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including familial pancreatic cancer syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists Familial Pancreatic Cancer Syndrome and describes criteria and associated risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes BRCA1/BRCA2 with associated pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions Lynch syndrome (mismatch repair defects) and its association with pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists STK11 (Peutz-Jeghers syndrome) and notes elevated pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma (FAMMM) among rare syndromes; minor spelling variant noted but content is correct.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention hereditary pancreatitis (e.g., PRSS1) as a risk syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises consulting a genetic counselor/medical geneticist but does not specifically recommend consulting an oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends consulting a genetic counselor or medical geneticist for personalized assessment and testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that routine screening is not recommended for the general population.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses surveillance in high-risk groups and post-treatment settings but does not explicitly state that routine screening is not recommended for the general population.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention MRI as a surveillance modality for high-risk individuals.
criterion_scores.justification: MRI is listed as a surveillance imaging modality, and the response links surveillance to high-risk individuals (e.g., IPMN and hereditary risk), including annual EUS or MRI for precancerous lesions.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that surveillance typically starts around age 50 and continues annually.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of a typical start age around 50 or an explicit statement that surveillance continues annually for high-risk individuals; instead, it mentions starting in 30s–40s for hereditary syndromes and varying intervals.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the evidence for screening/surveillance is not well established and mention the risk of overdiagnosis leading to unnecessary stress and procedures.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses over-surveillance, anxiety, false positives/negatives, and unnecessary procedures, it does not explicitly state that the evidence for screening/surveillance is not well established, nor does it explicitly use the concept of overdiagnosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that people at high risk may benefit from screening.
criterion_scores.justification: The response indicates that high-risk individuals may require earlier and more intensive surveillance, implying benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a significant family history of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions a strong family history (e.g., first-degree relatives) as a reason for genetic testing and counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a known genetic syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists hereditary syndromes such as BRCA1/2 and Lynch syndrome as indications for genetic testing and tailored surveillance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a history of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Chronic pancreatitis is not identified as a high-risk category; pancreatitis is only mentioned in the context of elevating CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include EUS as a screening modality to detect pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: EUS is highlighted as highly sensitive for detecting small tumors and for monitoring cystic lesions, fulfilling its role as a screening/surveillance modality.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises patients to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate surveillance strategy and discusses potential harms such as anxiety and unnecessary procedures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Genetic testing and counseling are recommended for those with strong family history or hereditary syndromes, and genetic counselors are included in the multidisciplinary team, implying discussion of risks and benefits.

criterion_scores.description: Include surgery as a potential treatment modality for resectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly discusses surgical options (Whipple, distal pancreatectomy, total pancreatectomy) with curative intent for early-stage/localized (resectable) disease and notes eligibility limitations.

criterion_scores.description: Specify that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer, with main regimens being FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: While chemotherapy is discussed and FOLFIRINOX is named, the response does not mention gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel specifically and does not clearly state chemotherapy as the backbone for metastatic/unresectable disease.

criterion_scores.description: Include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Radiation therapy is described, including neoadjuvant/adjuvant use and SBRT for localized, inoperable tumors.

criterion_scores.description: State that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states treatment depends on tumor stage and reiterates staging as a key consideration.

criterion_scores.description: State that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the co-morbidities of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "overall health" but does not explicitly reference co-morbidities influencing treatment decisions.

criterion_scores.description: State that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the functional status of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly mention functional or performance status as a determinant; tolerance to side effects is noted but not framed as performance status guiding therapy.

criterion_scores.description: Include immunotherapy, noting its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Immunotherapy is discussed, but the response does not restrict its role to MSI-H/dMMR cases and suggests broader approvals (including nivolumab), which is inaccurate for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Correctly mentions PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib) for BRCA-mutated tumors.

criterion_scores.description: Introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear section on clinical trials, emphasizing their importance and examples of investigational approaches.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes Tis as 'tumor in situ' and non-invasive but does not explicitly state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state nor mention pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) or 'carcinoma in situ' by name; it also refers to it as 'cancer,' which is imprecise for Stage 0.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: Stage I is described as T1 N0 M0, confined to the pancreas with no lymph node or distant spread, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention Stage IA or specify that IA corresponds to a tumor 2 cm or smaller.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention Stage IB; it instead places T2 (>2 cm) in Stage II, which does not satisfy the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: While lymph node involvement is mentioned for Stage II, the response does not state that Stage II involves growth into nearby tissues; it characterizes T2 as still confined to the pancreas.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: The response characterizes Stage III as locally advanced with extension beyond the pancreas into adjacent tissues and involving surrounding structures, satisfying the criterion despite some staging inaccuracies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that Stage IV includes distant metastasis (M1) to organs such as liver, lungs, and peritoneum.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: The response introduces the AJCC TNM system and describes T, N, and M categories across stages, fulfilling the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability (resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced/unresectable, metastatic). It only mentions resectability incidentally without presenting this categorization.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states neuropathy is a known side effect of oxaliplatin, a component of FOLFIRINOX.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly mention holding or temporarily stopping oxaliplatin; discusses adjusting/removing or switching regimens instead.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of dose reduction of oxaliplatin for neuropathy management.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of schedule modification strategies (e.g., omitting oxaliplatin cycles or altering infusion intervals).

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly recommends switching to regimens without oxaliplatin (e.g., FOLFIRI, gemcitabine-based, CAPIRI).

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions gemcitabine alone and gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Supportive medications listed include pregabalin, duloxetine, and amitriptyline; gabapentin is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Duloxetine (an SNRI) is listed as a supportive option.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Pregabalin is explicitly mentioned as a supportive medication.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly urges consultation with the oncologist regarding neuropathy and treatment changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises clarifying endpoints (what the trial measures, e.g., survival, QoL, tumor response) and explains trial phases, both of which convey the trial’s purpose/aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Benefits are explicitly listed (access to new therapies, potential better outcomes, contributing to research).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Risks are clearly outlined (unknown/severe side effects, no benefit, delay in receiving standard treatment).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria with examples (biomarkers, prior treatments).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions duration, frequency of visits/procedures, and a specific 'Time Commitment' section discussing adherence and energy levels.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a 'Costs and Insurance' section covering coverage of treatment, travel, lodging, insurance, and financial assistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear explanation of trial phases I–IV and their implications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: While trial design and control groups are discussed, there is no mention of crossover options between arms.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes neoadjuvant radiation for borderline resectable tumors to shrink them, make them operable, and improve chances of surgical removal.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on unresectable/locally advanced disease detailing chemoradiation and common regimens.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes a palliative radiation section covering pain relief, relief of obstruction, quality-of-life improvement, and techniques such as SBRT and hypofractionation.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Key Considerations' explicitly stratify recommendations by stage (early-stage, locally advanced, metastatic).

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that overall health and performance status influence treatment choices.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: Although vessel involvement is mentioned for borderline resectable disease, the response does not explicitly state the goal of sterilizing vessel margins.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: For locally advanced/unresectable disease, the response states radiation (with systemic therapy) aims to slow tumor growth and prolong survival, which aligns with delaying progression.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: The neoadjuvant and adjuvant sections mention reducing the risk of recurrence and targeting residual microscopic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that pancreatic cancer can impair pancreatic function, leading to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and insufficient enzyme production.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that enzymes are needed to break down carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, and that deficiency leads to malabsorption with symptoms such as bloating, diarrhea, weight loss, and malnutrition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that enzyme supplements are designed to replace or supplement the digestive enzymes the pancreas is not producing adequately.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that supplements help digest food and absorb nutrients and explicitly notes they aim to improve digestion and reduce symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes cancer-associated hypercoagulability, mentions 'cancer-associated thrombosis,' and explains that tumors release procoagulant substances increasing clot risk. This clearly states the association between cancer and increased blood clot risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response directly notes that pancreatic cancer can increase the risk of blood clots and references Trousseau’s syndrome in pancreatic cancer. It also ties the patient's DVT to the cancer as a likely related factor, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends seeking a second opinion soon after diagnosis and in complex/uncertain cases, but it does not explicitly say they can be obtained at any time, nor does it clearly include during treatment or when considering clinical trials as specific times.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mention that second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes seeking a second opinion after initial diagnosis and early in planning, but does not explicitly mention 'before starting treatment' nor does it mention the scenario when initial treatment is no longer effective.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Lack of Clarity or Trust' it states, 'If you’re unsure about the diagnosis (e.g., conflicting test results)...' which explicitly addresses diagnostic uncertainty.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes disagreement about stage ('if there’s disagreement among doctors about the stage') and suggests asking, 'What is your interpretation of the test results and staging?' which explicitly covers staging uncertainty.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions seeking a second opinion when 'the diagnosis or recommended treatment feels unclear' and if the 'proposed treatment... seems risky or unclear.'

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: In 'Identify a Qualified Specialist,' it directs patients to 'Academic medical centers or "cancer centers of excellence"' and to seek specialists with training in pancreatic cancer, indicating specialized referral centers for second opinions.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references ASCO, PanCAN, and NCCN, but does not mention NCI-designated cancer centers.

criterion_scores.description: Mention major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'Academic medical centers... often have specialists in this area,' which clearly points to major academic hospitals as resources.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: While NCCN is referenced generally, the response does not specifically state that NCCN guidelines recommend evaluation at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention mismatch repair deficiency (dMMR) or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H) as the key subgroup for which immunotherapy is effective/approved in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly emphasizes that immunotherapy is an evolving option, that research is advancing, and that combination strategies are under investigation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there may be clinical trial options exploring novel immunotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly discusses clinical trials, including CAR-T, vaccines, and bispecific antibodies, and advises how to find trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immune checkpoint blockade is only approved for patients with metastatic disease in certain situations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not specify the approval context (e.g., metastatic disease) or that approval is limited to specific situations; it speaks generally about use in advanced disease without clarifying approval status.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pembrolizumab is approved for patients whose tumors are TMB high.
criterion_scores.justification: While TMB testing is mentioned, the response does not state that pembrolizumab has a tissue-agnostic approval for TMB-high tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking their oncology team about testing for eligibility for immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends consulting the oncology team, highlights biomarker testing (e.g., TMB), and encourages asking whether immunotherapy is appropriate for the specific cancer profile, which implies testing for eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should consult with their oncologist on the potential next steps.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises consulting the oncologist again and even suggests seeking a second opinion and involving a multidisciplinary team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest alternative standard of care therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions the oncologist may suggest different chemotherapy regimens and radiation therapy, which are standard options after progression. While some targeted therapy examples (e.g., ivosidenib) are not standard for pancreatic cancer, the criterion of noting alternative standard-of-care therapies is fulfilled.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section recommends exploring clinical trials, advises discussing them with the oncologist, and provides reputable resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that re-biopsy of the disease could reveal targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it recommends tumor genomic profiling, it does not explicitly mention re-biopsy at progression as a means to identify new targetable mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend supportive care and symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly recommends palliative/supportive care, hospice when appropriate, and specific symptom management strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no approved CAR-T cell therapy for pancreatic cancer at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that CAR-T therapy is not yet FDA-approved for pancreatic cancer and is not standard practice, clearly conveying the lack of approved indication.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe CAR-T cells.
criterion_scores.justification: It accurately describes CAR-T therapy as genetically modifying a patient’s own T cells to target and destroy cancer cells, which is a clear and correct description.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are being studied in clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly notes ongoing clinical trials for pancreatic cancer, lists example targets (mesothelin, EGFR, CLDN18), and cites an NCT trial number, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are approved for the treatment of other types of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that CAR-T therapy is primarily approved for blood cancers and mentions leukemia and lymphoma, fulfilling the requirement. Minor unrelated inaccuracy (calling gemcitabine a targeted therapy) does not affect this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice is considered when the medical team estimates a life expectancy of 6 months or less.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states hospice is typically considered when prognosis is 6 months or less based on medical evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the aim of hospice is to maximize quality of life and focus on addressing symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly emphasizes comfort, quality of life, and relief from pain and symptoms over curative treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice can take place in the home, a nursing home, or in a dedicated hospice facility.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes care can be provided at home, in a nursing home, hospital, or hospice facility.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: The response begins with a descriptive definition of hospice without an initial expression of sympathy or support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Hospice is defined as specialized support focusing on comfort, dignity, and quality of life when curative treatments are no longer effective or desired.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including emotional and spiritual support.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly includes counseling, spiritual guidance, and emotional support for patients and families.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including bereavement support.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions bereavement support and grief counseling for families.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that fatigue is a common side effect of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response discusses 'chemotherapy-induced fatigue,' it does not explicitly state that fatigue is a common side effect of chemotherapy or mention its prevalence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises discussing fatigue with the oncologist or nurse, considering treatment adjustments, and involving palliative care.

criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on 'Nutrition and Hydration' recommending nutrient-dense foods, small frequent meals, hydration, and potential supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend good sleep hygiene.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides specific sleep hygiene strategies, including consistent schedules, bedtime routines, limiting screens, and optimizing the sleep environment.

criterion_scores.justification: It mentions possible contributors such as anemia, infection, medication side effects, depression, and pain, but does not state that the cancer itself can cause fatigue.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that light physical activity can improve fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends light exercise (e.g., short walks, stretching) to boost energy and suggests involving a physical therapist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend medication review.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises discussing medication side effects with the medical team and mentions potential pharmacologic options, consistent with a medication review.

criterion_scores.description: State that alternative treatments like cannabis oil have not been proven to help patients with pancreatic cancer live longer or cure them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states cannabis oil is 'not a proven cure' and that 'its efficacy for treating the disease itself remains unproven,' which addresses lack of evidence for cure or survival benefit.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is sometimes used to manage cancer-related symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly notes most research focuses on 'symptom management' and lists pain, nausea, and appetite stimulation as potential benefits.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing the use of cannabis oil with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly advises consulting the oncology team and discussing cannabis use with the oncologist, including potential drug interactions and integrative medicine programs.

criterion_scores.description: Describe cannabis oil.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes cannabis oil/products as containing cannabinoids such as THC and CBD, and mentions forms (oils, tinctures, edibles) and CBD-dominant options, providing an adequate description.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is not used as an anti-cancer treatment per guidelines.
criterion_scores.justification: It states cannabis oil is 'not a proven cure,' that it should 'not replace' surgery/chemotherapy/radiation, and emphasizes adhering to evidence-based treatments—consistent with guideline-based use.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including drug interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: It warns about interactions with chemotherapy via CYP450 metabolism and urges consultation with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Side effects listed include dizziness, fatigue, dry mouth, anxiety/paranoia (with high THC), and potential long-term cognitive/mental health impacts.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including variation in quality.
criterion_scores.justification: It highlights quality control concerns such as contaminants and inconsistent cannabinoid levels, recommending lab-tested reputable products.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including legal concerns.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated legal section covers variability of laws by jurisdiction, access requirements, and caregiver responsibilities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that lack of appetite is a common side effect of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response discusses appetite loss in pancreatic cancer, it does not explicitly state that it is a common side effect.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should consult with their oncologist, who may refer them to a registered dietitian, oncology nutritionist, and/or palliative care physician to address symptoms and optimize supportive care.

criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and that enzyme supplements may be required, which is pancreatic enzyme replacement.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that bowel changes can also be due to infections.
criterion_scores.justification: C. difficile and infection risk are explicitly cited as causes of diarrhea.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing specific concerns with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting the medical team and specifically encourages discussing changes with their oncologist or gastroenterologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends keeping a log of events related to food intake, fluid intake, and bowel symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests tracking stool-related symptoms but does not recommend logging food or fluid intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the above log with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: No suggestion to bring or discuss a symptom/food/fluid log with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient has not had a bowel movement in more than 24 hours and is not passing gas, their bowels may be obstructed, which is a medical emergency and requires immediate evaluation in an emergency department.
criterion_scores.justification: Bowel obstruction is mentioned, but no specific red-flag guidance about >24 hours without BM and no gas or ED urgency.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient is nauseous and unable to keep any food or drink down without vomiting, this can quickly lead to severe dehydration, which requires urgent evaluation by a medical professional and potentially intravenous fluids and medicines.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit advice regarding inability to keep fluids down, dehydration risk, or need for urgent evaluation/IV fluids.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient is experiencing severe abdominal pain, this may represent a medical emergency which requires immediate evaluation in an emergency department.
criterion_scores.justification: Severe abdominal pain as an emergency/ED indication is not addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response says patients with pancreatic cancer may experience pancreatic insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic insufficiency is explicitly named as a potential cause due to ductal blockage.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains pancreatic insufficiency is related to a deficiency in the pancreatic enzymes which break down food and can cause diarrhea and bloating.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that inadequate enzyme release leads to malabsorption causing steatorrhea and diarrhea; mechanism of enzyme deficiency is clearly described.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains there are supplementary pancreatic enzymes that can be taken to alleviate the symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions enzyme supplements for pancreatic insufficiency to help manage symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains if the bowel changes are due to chemotherapy, the treating oncologist can often prescribe additional medications to control these side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: While medications like anti-diarrheals are mentioned, it does not specifically state that the oncologist can prescribe additional medications for chemo-related side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response says proper nutrition is an important part of cancer care outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: Nutrition is referenced for symptom management, but it does not state its importance for overall cancer care outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response says it is important to remain hydrated.
criterion_scores.justification: Hydration is recommended as part of supportive care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that it is important to determine the cause of the bowel changes to manage them effectively.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes evaluation to determine the exact cause and appropriate care, including testing to pinpoint the cause.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that gastric outlet/duodenal obstruction can occur in up to 10% of patients with pancreatic cancer, leading to symptoms like early satiety, nausea, postprandial vomiting, and weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of gastric outlet/duodenal obstruction prevalence or its characteristic symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that patients with malignant ascites from pancreatic cancer may experience abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting.
criterion_scores.justification: Malignant ascites is not discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that diet/nutrition changes can cause bowel changes unrelated to cancer or cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not explicitly state that diet changes unrelated to cancer/treatment can alter bowel habits.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that stress/anxiety can cause bowel changes unrelated to cancer or cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Stress/anxiety as a cause of bowel changes is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pre-existing conditions can cause bowel changes unrelated to cancer or cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Pre-existing GI conditions or other comorbidities are not cited as potential causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises consulting the oncologist/medical team and emphasizes it as critical.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pancreatic cancer and its treatments may affect the patient’s ability to drive safely.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses chemotherapy/treatment effects on driving but does not state that pancreatic cancer itself may affect driving ability.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pain medications may impair the patient’s ability to drive safely.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly notes pain medications can cause drowsiness/impaired judgment affecting driving.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that symptoms such as fatigue, drowsiness, nausea, and vomiting may impair the patient’s ability to drive safely.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions fatigue, nausea/vomiting, and drowsiness (from medications) as impacting driving.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the patient’s healthcare team may have resources to assist with transportation.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests alternative transportation and external organizations but does not state that the healthcare team can provide transportation resources (e.g., social work services).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that chemotherapy can cause fatigue that may impair driving abilities.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states chemotherapy-related fatigue can slow reaction times and reduce alertness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that chemotherapy can cause vision changes that may impair driving abilities.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions monitoring for blurred vision but does not attribute vision changes to chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that chemotherapy can cause neuropathy that may impair driving abilities.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of neuropathy or its impact on pedal control/sensation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that chemotherapy can cause cognitive changes that may impair driving abilities.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly references 'chemo brain' affecting concentration, memory, and decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to avoid driving after the first chemotherapy session to see how your husband tolerates it.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not specifically advise avoiding driving after the first chemotherapy session.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to plan for backup transportation, such as a taxi, friends/family, or public transportation.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends rideshare, friends/family, and public transit as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) provides information on medical conditions and driving safety.
criterion_scores.justification: References the American Cancer Society and CancerCare but not NHTSA.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the ability to work depends on individual circumstances such as the stage of cancer, overall health, and comorbidities.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly says working during treatment depends on individual factors and details stage/type (early vs advanced). While it does not explicitly name comorbidities, it clearly frames the decision as individualized and tied to cancer stage and personal factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the ability to work depends on the type of treatment (chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, targeted therapy) and related side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses surgery recovery and side effects from chemotherapy and radiation (fatigue, nausea, weakened immunity), linking these to impact on stamina and work capacity.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the ability to work depends on the support available from friends, family, and caregivers.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions workplace support and emotional support resources but does not state that support from friends, family, or personal caregivers influences the ability to work.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the ability to work depends on job type and flexibility (working from home, reduced hours, workplace accommodations, scheduled breaks).
criterion_scores.justification: It directly addresses job demands and flexibility and lists accommodations such as remote work, part-time hours, flexible start/end times, modified duties, and ADA accommodations including breaks.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pancreatic cancer and its treatment can cause symptoms which may make working challenging.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes fatigue, pain, digestive issues, and treatment-related effects (e.g., nausea, weakened immunity) that can vary day-to-day and affect work.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises consulting the oncologist and a nurse navigator, and mentions referrals to a social worker or occupational therapist for strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends workplace accommodations which may make working possible during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It proposes specific accommodations (reduced hours, flexible scheduling, telecommuting, modified duties) and cites ADA reasonable accommodations including breaks.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the patient’s ability to continue working should be continually reassessed as their medical condition changes.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes that every case is unique, encourages adjusting plans as needed, and acknowledges that treatment may become too taxing, prompting a leave of absence—implying ongoing reassessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that self-care is important while undergoing cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly prioritizes health, recommends rest and avoiding overexertion, and suggests planning for low-energy days and seeking emotional support.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the patient may qualify for paid leave through their employer, the government, or both.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions FMLA (unpaid) and suggests disability benefits/insurance generally, but does not explicitly state eligibility for paid leave through employer or government programs.

criterion_scores.description: The response states many patients with pancreatic cancer take time off of work during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It says some people need to step back or take leave, but does not state that many patients take time off during treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that it is important for patients with pancreatic cancer to maintain their quality of life, and that work during treatment may be possible.
criterion_scores.justification: It affirms that working during treatment is often possible and highlights maintaining normalcy and emotional well-being, aligning with quality-of-life considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing the use of medical marijuana with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'Consult His Oncologist' and 'Work closely with your father’s healthcare team' and emphasizes reviewing interactions and dosing with clinicians.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that medical marijuana is not an effective alternative treatment for pancreatic cancer itself.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states 'It is not a cure for cancer but may improve quality of life.'

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions risks and side effects associated with medical marijuana, including psychoactive effects and potential interactions with other medications.
criterion_scores.justification: Side effects listed include dizziness, drowsiness, impaired memory/concentration, dependency, and mental health concerns; it also advises reviewing drug interactions with chemotherapy, painkillers, and blood thinners. THC is identified as psychoactive.

criterion_scores.description: The response clearly states that medical marijuana comes in various forms, such as oils, edibles, tinctures, and vaporizers.
criterion_scores.justification: Forms listed include vaporizers, oils/tinctures, capsules, edibles, topicals, sublingual drops, and suppositories.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions the risk of inhaled medical marijuana exposing patients to infectious organisms like fungi, particularly for those receiving certain chemotherapy treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of infectious risks (e.g., fungal contamination) associated with inhaled products or special risks for immunocompromised/chemotherapy patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that medical marijuana may be used to control symptoms associated with pancreatic cancer and its treatments, such as nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Benefits listed include pain relief, chemotherapy-induced nausea/vomiting, appetite stimulation, sleep, and mood.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that there is mixed data on the benefit of medical marijuana for managing symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes 'Research is ongoing, and effectiveness varies by individual' and that 'some studies show benefits... but evidence... is limited,' indicating mixed evidence.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses potential legal challenges with obtaining and using medical marijuana, noting that these may vary based on the patient’s location.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed location-specific legal considerations (state vs. federal discrepancies, requirements for medical cards, and employment/travel implications).

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends not driving or making important decisions while under the influence of marijuana.
criterion_scores.justification: While cognitive side effects are mentioned, there is no explicit advice to avoid driving or important decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends obtaining medical marijuana only from professionals licensed to sell it.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends using licensed dispensaries for quality control and access.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that medical marijuana refers to products derived from the cannabis plant or its extracts that contain active compounds such as THC (tetrahydrocannabinol), CBD (cannabidiol), or combinations thereof.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains key components (THC and CBD, with full names), their effects, and notes products vary in THC:CBD ratios, effectively describing medical cannabis as products containing these compounds.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that preliminary data reports poor clinical outcomes in adults receiving immunotherapy while using cannabis and/or cannabinoids.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of immunotherapy outcomes or the potential for poorer outcomes with concurrent cannabis use.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that CBD presents risks for hepatotoxicity, with a meta-analysis reporting a nearly 6-fold increase in liver enzyme elevation and drug-induced liver injury.
criterion_scores.justification: Hepatotoxicity and liver enzyme elevation risks with CBD are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cannabis and/or cannabinoids are one of several pharmacologic options for adults with cancer experiencing refractory nausea and vomiting despite optimal prophylaxis.
criterion_scores.justification: Although chemotherapy-induced nausea is mentioned and dronabinol noted, it does not specify use for refractory symptoms after optimal prophylaxis among several options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that further research is needed to determine the effectiveness of cannabis to reduce polypharmacy.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of polypharmacy reduction or research needs related to it.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that further research is needed to determine the effectiveness of cannabis to reduce opioid requirements for cancer-related pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address opioid-sparing effects or the need for research in this area.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that further research is needed to determine the effectiveness of cannabis to reduce chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy or cannabis effects on it.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that further research is needed to determine the effects of cannabis on pain.
criterion_scores.justification: While pain relief is listed as a potential benefit, it does not explicitly state that further research is needed regarding cannabis’s effects on pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends consulting with the patient’s oncologist or healthcare team, including specific roles such as nurse practitioner or palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises, “Request a meeting with the oncologist or care team,” and outlines topics to clarify (prognosis, options, expectations, timeline). While it does not explicitly name a nurse practitioner or palliative care specialist, it clearly recommends consultation with the oncologist/healthcare team, satisfying the core requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that the healthcare team may have a social worker available to assist with family discussions.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly suggests using “a social worker from the hospital” to guide the family conversation, indicating availability through the care setting to assist with family discussions.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends involving a neutral third party, such as a social worker, spiritual care worker, counselor, or patient advocate, to facilitate family discussions.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends a neutral facilitator and lists examples (trusted friend, therapist, hospital social worker) and separately mentions family mediation with a therapist or conflict resolution specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly provides online resources for cancer patients and their families, including specific organizations like PANCAN, NCI, or ACS.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides specific online resources, including Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PANCAN) and the American Cancer Society (ACS), as well as CancerCare and Cancer Support Community.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend scheduling a family meeting to discuss goals of care and important treatment decisions.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends hosting a family meeting, with structure and goals focused on shared understanding and decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that understanding your mother’s specific goals should shape conversations about goals of care and treatment recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly centers the mother’s priorities (e.g., “What does your mother value most?”) and advises using her advance directives and values (substituted judgment/best interest) to guide decisions, aligning care with her goals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that your mother’s wishes related to treatment, belief systems, and personal ways of coping should be respected by their families, cancer care team, and others who support them through the cancer experience.
criterion_scores.justification: While it emphasizes honoring the mother’s values and humanity, it does not explicitly state that her treatment wishes, beliefs, and coping styles should be respected by both family and the cancer care team and other supporters.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response refers broadly to the healthcare team but does not explicitly recommend discussing concerns with the patient's oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a social worker, spiritual care worker, palliative care professional, or counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends professional counseling, involving a spiritual advisor, and consulting a hospital social worker.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends support groups and other online resources for cancer patients and their families.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends support groups and provides links to PanCAN and the American Cancer Society.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that depression is highly prevalent in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Depression is not mentioned as being highly prevalent in pancreatic cancer specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews the signs and symptoms of depression.
criterion_scores.justification: No signs or symptoms of depression are described.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that if the patient is experiencing thoughts of harming themselves or others, they should seek immediate evaluation by a healthcare professional.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of urgent evaluation for suicidal or homicidal thoughts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that it’s important to have open and honest conversations about their concerns, including feeling like a burden to their loved ones.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes open and honest communication and specifically addresses validating concerns about feeling like a burden.

criterion_scores.description: The response should encourage the patient to express their fears and anxieties about the impact of their illness on their loved ones, and acknowledge and validate their feelings.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises acknowledging feelings, encouraging expression of fears, and validating concerns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to ask about the patient’s preferences and personal goals of care.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests discussing and documenting healthcare preferences (advance directives) and creating a patient-centered care plan, aligning with goals-of-care discussions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention it is important to emphasize working together to manage the challenges.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly emphasizes collaboration, shared task planning, family meetings, and that the journey is a shared effort.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention support networks such as PanCAN, CancerCare, ASCO.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN); the criterion allows examples such as these.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that professional counseling can help process these emotions.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly recommends professional counseling to help process guilt, fear, and anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies work against cancer with specific genetic mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains targeted therapy "focuses on specific molecules or pathways" and emphasizes genetic testing for mutations (e.g., KRAS, BRAF, HER2, NTRK), indicating it works against cancers with specific genetic alterations.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that not all pancreatic cancers will have mutations for which targeted therapy can be used.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states "Not all pancreatic cancers have the targeted mutations, so effectiveness varies."

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of targetable mutations in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists KRAS, BRAF, HER2, NTRK, and BRCA as potential targetable alterations.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies can be given alone or sometimes in combination with chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes targeted therapy is "often used alongside chemotherapy or immunotherapy" but does not clearly state that targeted therapy can be given alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The "Next Steps" section explicitly advises asking the oncologist specific questions about mutations, targeted therapies, benefits/risks, and clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that targeted therapy for pancreatic cancer involves using drugs to specifically target proteins, genes, or pathways of cancer cells, potentially causing less damage to normal cells compared to chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It states targeted therapy focuses on "specific proteins, genes, or other molecules" and contrasts with chemotherapy by noting "often with fewer side effects," implying less damage to normal cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that while targeted therapy is an option, it is important to consider all potential treatment options, outcomes, and adverse events to make an informed decision.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends discussing expected benefits/risks with the oncologist and considering clinical trials, reflecting the need to weigh options, outcomes, and adverse events.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention examples of targeted therapies, such as Dabrafenib + trametinib (if BRAF V600E mutation-positive), Entrectinib, Larotrectinib, Repotrectinib (if NTRK gene fusion-positive), Selpercatinib (if RET gene fusion-positive), Rucaparib (for germline or somatic BRCA1/2 or PALB2 mutations), Olaparib (only for germline BRCA1/2 mutations), Adagrasib (if KRAS G12C mutation-positive), Sotorasib (if KRAS G12C mutation-positive), Erdafitinib (if FGFR genetic alterations), Fam-trastuzumab deruxtecan-nxki (if HER2 positive [IHC3+ or IHC2+ with FISH HER2 amplified]) Zenocutuzumab-zbco (if NRG1 gene fusion-positive).
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes examples from the list (e.g., olaparib and dabrafenib), satisfying the requirement to mention such agents.

criterion_scores.description: Negative points if targeted therapies are discussed that are not approved for pancreatic cancer, such as osimertinib, regorafenib, mTOR inhibitors.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists cetuximab and bevacizumab as examples in pancreatic cancer; these are not approved for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, constituting discussion of non-approved targeted therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing integrative medicine with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises: “Discuss with the Oncologist… Inform your loved one’s medical team about any integrative approaches being considered,” and emphasizes coordination with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine is not as effective as standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer like chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, and targeted therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly frames integrative care as supportive for side effects and quality of life and states it should “never replace evidence-based cancer treatments,” implying it is not as effective for treating the cancer itself as SOC.

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine can be a helpful adjunct to standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States: “Integrative medicine can complement conventional care by addressing symptoms and enhancing quality of life,” and repeatedly positions it alongside—not instead of—standard treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines integrative medicine.
criterion_scores.justification: While it describes how to use integrative therapies and that they complement conventional care, it does not provide a clear, explicit definition of integrative medicine as a coordinated approach combining evidence-based complementary therapies with conventional treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of integrative medicine interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple examples: acupuncture, meditation, yoga, nutrition/dietary modifications, supplements (omega-3, vitamin D), physical activity, art therapy, and support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist if they plan to include integrative medicine interventions into their care plan.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly instructs to inform the oncology team about any integrative approaches being considered and to coordinate care.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist about all supplements they are taking.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically says to discuss supplements with the oncology team, to disclose use to the medical team, and to document all supplements for the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states some supplements may interact with the treatments being prescribed for their pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes that certain herbs/supplements (e.g., turmeric/curcumin, garlic, ginger) may interfere with chemotherapy or blood thinners, highlighting interaction risks.

criterion_scores.description: The response states there is data to support some integrative medicine interventions for specific uses.
